p.seg: THE BANK 8II.O OF PETER BERGQUIST. ATLANTA, NEBR. Doors are provided up and down the side of the silo opposite the passage, so the silage can be thrown from the bilo into the common Utter carrier which runs out over the feed bunks, as shown in the cut.

BULLETIN NO. 139. The University of Nebraska. BULLETIN OF THE AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION OF NEBRASKA. Volume XXVI, Article I. DAIRY HERD RECORDS FOR FOURTEEN YEARS By J. H. Fbandsen ai»d A. L. Haecker. Distributed April 6, 1914. LINCOLN. NEBRASKA. USA.

BY J. H. FRANDSEX AND A. U HAECKEH. Since the publication of Bulletin \o. 101, which gave the herd records from 1807 to 190f>. inclusive, there have been completed four more yearly records and all fourteen will here be given. Since the founding of the herd in October, 1896. a regular system of records has lieen kept and care taken to account for all prodiiHion of milk and fat by individual animals and breeds. All grain rations have also lteen kept, and at certain seasons when special exjKriinents were in progress all roughage was weighed Ke herd was managed in the following manner: For keeping Is, weekly milk sheets were kept in the barn and all milkings led in pounds and tenths of a pound. A composite test was f each animal, and the weekly fat production found in this ?r. Each animal was weighed every week for the first seven of the test, and every other week for the latter seven. To variation, care was taken to use the same system of weighing ! the cows were turned out of the barn. Each animal was managed with the intention of securing both a lactation record and a calf each year. It wag attempted to give each animal a rest of a few weeks before freshening, and as a rule they were bred three months after freshening. Many of the cows were persistent milkers and it was often difficult to turn them dry so as to give them a rest. The rations have been made with the plan of balancing both grain and roughage. The grain has always been fed in amounts according to the animal's capacity, this being measured by what she would use for milk production. With many of the cows their capacity was found by what they could eat up clean, while others would fatten, and in such cases their ration was cut down, as few animals gained in milk while fattening. An effort was made to keep all the cows in a thrifty condition, but to avoid fattening them. The yearly records here given are compiled from the record BMr. A. L. Haecker was Professor of Dairy Husbandry and in charge le department prior to 1911. Records in this bulletin prior to the » date were made under his supervision. BUL. 139, AGE. EXP. STATION OF NEBR. VOL. XXVI. ART. I.

4 tks, where each animal's record is entered in units of weeks, changes in feeding and rations were made on Sunday morn i as the calendar week was used. The summer management of the herd was to turn them to pasture when the grass was fit for grazing and to stable them only at milking time. The pasture season averaged about six months per year, but during drouth years the grass was poor during the months of July and August. When the grass was poor or short, the cattle had access to alfalfa hay in racks. Little grain was fed during good pasture seasons, but some was always fed to encour - age the animals to take their stalls in the barn. Large milkers were fed more grain than those giving small amounts, but the herd always received less grain when the pasture was good. The winter feeding generally started in October and continued until May. The plan of feeding was as follows: The milking started at 4: 00 a. m., at which time the cows all received grain, and after milking a feed of corn silage was given. This was supplied in rations of from 10 to 20 pounds ]>er cow. At 8 : 30 or 9 : 00 a. m.. all were turned out into the yard, where they had free access to alfalfa hay in rack, and to water and salt. This yard was pro - vided with a shed running along the north side, which broke the tld north and northwest winds and also furnished a shelter in d weather. B health of the herd has been good during all the years of nd this no doubt was largely due to the good air and water received by the animals. The barn was well ventilated by ir flues and windows. The water was supplied by a t that required turning on each day. By this method the was always fresh and much better than where a float valve is used. The water tank was emptied and scrubbed out once a week and rinsed with a solution of copper snlfate. which pre - vented the growth of plant life on the bottom or walls of the tank- All animals added to the herd were first tested for tuberculosis and purchased only when found in good health. The herd was tested twice a year, in spring and fall, and all animals that re acted were removed from the herd. The number reacting during the period of fourteen year* amounted to about 2 per cent. E animals of the herd had names, and under these their were kept in the books of the Department. Bv this the attendants .soon learned the individual animals and ger of making mistakes was greatly lessened. In the tables following, the yearly records of the herd are given and averages made for each year.

It is interesting to note iriation in the richness of the milk. A large

Eln reviewing the work of the herd for the fourteen years, it be seen that the average production per cow was 7.020.8 nds of milk and 341.71 pounds of butter. This yield, being nearly three times the amount produced by the average dairy cow of the state, indicates the great increase that may be obtained by proper breeding and feeding. The rations were made of Nebraska grown crops and feeds, and the principal roughage was corn silage and alfalfa hay, which can be produced by nearly every dairyman of the state. This herd from a financial standpoint yielded a handsome profit during all the years of the teRt and at the present time is in the very best of condition. Breed Year Age Days in milk Milk in lbs.
